c
operator returns the original JSON type (which might be an object), whereas
->>
c
returns text.

title: Select rows based on a value inside your JSON:

inline_content.Text: Select rows based on a value inside your JSON:

title:
SELECT 
client,
data->'title' AS title
FROM books
 WHERE data->'title' = '"Dharma Bums"';

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
client,
data->'title' AS title
FROM books
 WHERE data->'title' = '"Dharma Bums"';

title: Notice WHERE uses
->
c
so we must compare to JSON
'"Dharma Bums"'
c

title: Find rows based on the value of a nested JSON object:

inline_content.Text: Find rows based on the value of a nested JSON object:

title:
SELECT 
 client,
 data->'title' AS title
 FROM books
  WHERE data->'author'->>'last_name' = 'Kerouac';

content_resolved.code:
SELECT 
 client,
 data->'title' AS title
 FROM books
  WHERE data->'author'->>'last_name' = 'Kerouac';

title: We’re going to store events in this table, like pageviews. Each event has properties, which could be anything (e.g. current page) and also sends information about the browser (like OS, screen resolution, etc). Both of these are completely free form and could change over time (as we think of extra stuff to track).

inline_content.Text: We’re going to store events in this table, like pageviews. Each event has properties, which could be anything (e.g. current page) and also sends information about the browser (like OS, screen resolution, etc). Both of these are completely free form and could change over time (as we think of extra stuff to track).

title:
INSERT INTO events (name, visitor_id, properties, browser) VALUES
(
  'pageview', '1',
  '{ "page": "/" }',
  '{ "name": "Chrome", "os": "Mac", "resolution": { "x": 1440, "y": 900 } }'
),(
  'pageview', '2',
  '{ "page": "/" }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1920, "y": 1200 } }'
),(
  'pageview', '1',
  '{ "page": "/account" }',
  '{ "name": "Chrome", "os": "Mac", "resolution": { "x": 1440, "y": 900 } }'
),(
  'purchase', '5',
  '{ "amount": 10 }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1024, "y": 768 } }'
),(
  'purchase', '15',
  '{ "amount": 200 }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1280, "y": 800 } }'
),(
  'purchase', '15',
  '{ "amount": 500 }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1280, "y": 800 } }'
);

content_resolved.code:
INSERT INTO events (name, visitor_id, properties, browser) VALUES
(
  'pageview', '1',
  '{ "page": "/" }',
  '{ "name": "Chrome", "os": "Mac", "resolution": { "x": 1440, "y": 900 } }'
),(
  'pageview', '2',
  '{ "page": "/" }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1920, "y": 1200 } }'
),(
  'pageview', '1',
  '{ "page": "/account" }',
  '{ "name": "Chrome", "os": "Mac", "resolution": { "x": 1440, "y": 900 } }'
),(
  'purchase', '5',
  '{ "amount": 10 }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1024, "y": 768 } }'
),(
  'purchase', '15',
  '{ "amount": 200 }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1280, "y": 800 } }'
),(
  'purchase', '15',
  '{ "amount": 500 }',
  '{ "name": "Firefox", "os": "Windows", "resolution": { "x": 1280, "y": 800 } }'
);

title: Using the JSON operators, combined with traditional PostgreSQL aggregate functions, we can pull out whatever we want. You have the full might of an RDBMS at your disposal.

inline_content.Text: Using the JSON operators, combined with traditional PostgreSQL aggregate functions, we can pull out whatever we want. You have the full might of an RDBMS at your disposal.

title:
SELECT browser->>'name' AS browser, 
  count(browser)
  FROM events
  GROUP BY browser->>'name';

content_resolved.code:
SELECT browser->>'name' AS browser, 
  count(browser)
  FROM events
  GROUP BY browser->>'name';

title:
SELECT visitor_id, SUM(CAST(properties->>'amount' AS integer)) AS total
    FROM events
    WHERE CAST(properties->>'amount' AS integer) > 0
    GROUP BY visitor_id;

content_resolved.code:
SELECT visitor_id, SUM(CAST(properties->>'amount' AS integer)) AS total
    FROM events
    WHERE CAST(properties->>'amount' AS integer) > 0
    GROUP BY visitor_id;
